On 8/15/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:

> This ain't cod=
e, but maybe it'll help. Bear in mind I'm handcuffed by my
> bias towards J=
Unit 3.
>
> @BeforeClass makes a set up method run before running all the t=
ests in
> that test case class (any class with at least one @Test in it).
>=

> @BeforeSuite would make a set up method run before running all the tests=

> in an arbitrary JUnit 3-style test suite, which might be composed of
> t=
ests from multiple classes.


I think the difficulty here comes from the fa=
ct that in JUnit, test classes
and test suites are hard to tell apart.  If =
you look at a class, it's a
"test suite" if has a suite() method and a "tes=
t class" otherwise.  In
practice, I've always found that this blending made=
 it hard for me to
pinpoint a specific test or series of tests that I want =
to investigate and
either run in isolation of the others or eliminate tempo=
rarily from the run.

From that perspective, I can understand why David say=
s that "@BeforeClass"
is good enough and there is no need for @BeforeSuite,=
 since @BeforeClass can
play either role depending on whether the class it =
applies to has a suite()
or not.

I still think that this is suboptimal, si=
nce you will radically change the
way your test is configured if you remove=
 your suite() method, and suddenly,
a lot of before/after methods will no l=
onger be called...

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
